newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish shares extend loss, seen inching down.
newsitem.headline: Polish shares extend loss, seen inching down.

text.p: Polish shares fell in slightly higher turnover on Friday and analysts saw the market inching down early next week, extending the current profit-taking correction of the 11.1-percent rise since early September.
The WIG index fell 103.4 points, or 0.7 percent, to 14,718.4, and turnover rose 6.3 percent to 91.8 million zlotys ($32.8 million) on both markets as 46 issues fell, 18 rose and 16 were flat.
Analysts expected the market, which already fell 2.4 percent since the October 9 high of 15,078.7 points of the WIG index, to find support on 14,400 or 14,000.
"I believe we will still have falls but the profit-taking correction is unlikely to be a very deep one," said Wojciech Kossuth, an analyst at Bank Slaski brokerage.
Analysts said early next week some stocks' performance might still be influenced by their earnings reports for September, due after the market's close on Friday.

Mass privatisation NFI units fell 5.1 percent in 22.4-million-zloty turnover ($8 million) in the regular session and fell 4.6 percent in 15-million-zloty ($5.4 million) continuous trade, extending their 9.9-percent fall since October 10, but analysts saw them rebounding soon.

Traders said furniture maker Swarzedz, Friday's biggest main market's loser, fell 7.7 percent in thin 0.1-million-zloty ($35,710) trade after showing a September loss of 28.5 million zlotys ($10.2 million).
